clinical_study.brief_title: Rapid Postoperative Recovery Pathway in Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis.
clinical_study.official_title: Rapid Postoperative Recovery (Fast-track) Pathway in Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis: a Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock: the study will evaluate the clinical outcomes of an intra- and postoperative fast-track protocol in patients undergoing instrumented posterior arthrodesis surgery for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the Fast track protocol
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of an intra- and post-operative fast-track protocol in terms of postoperative pain management.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the Fast track protocol
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of an intra- and post-operative fast-track protocol in terms of duration/times of hospitalization

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the Fast track protocol
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of an intra- and post-operative fast-track protocol in terms of blood loss

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the Fast track protocol
primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of an intra- and post-operative fast-track protocol in terms of patient education in early recovery of function.

secondary_outcome.description: evaluation of the hemocytometric examination (performed as per normal clinical practice).
evaluation of the main circulating inflammatory mediators.
evaluation of culture examinations on the surgical wound drainage fluid and microstructural analysis of the surgical drainage tube by scanning electron microscope.

intervention.description: Multidisciplinary approach alongside the orthopedic surgeon

study_pop.textblock: Adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis treatable by surgical procedure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ages 14-18 years
- iagnosis of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis requiring an instrumented posterior arthrodesis surgical procedure
- Males and females.
Exclusion Criteria:
- spinal infection
- neoplastic diseases
- heart disease
- hypersensitivity to tranexamic acid
- history of coagulopathy and/or previous thromboembolic events
- severe renal failure
